question_text: 1. Let the line x + y = 1 meet the circle x2 + y2 = 4 at the points A and B. If the line perpendicular to AB and passing through the mid point of the chord AB intersects the circle at C and D, then the area of the quadrilateral ADBC is equal to
solution: y y=x x A D B C By solving x = y with circle We get C( 2, 2) D(– 2,– 2) By solving x + y = 1 with circle x2 + y2 = 4 we set A  ,   1  7 1  7      2 2 &  B  ,   1  7 1  7      2 2 Area of Quadrilateral ACBD = 2 × Area of BCD =  2  1 1 1  7 1  7  2 – 2 1 2 2 1 2 2 2 = 2 14

6.  Let P be the set of seven digit numbers with sum of their digits equal to 11. If the numbers in P are formed by using the digits 1,2 and 3 only, then the number of elements in the set P is :
solution: (i) number of numbers created using 1111133 =  5!2!  21 7! (ii) number of numbers created using 1111223 =  4!2!  105 7! (iii) number of numbers created using 1112222 =  4!3!  35 7! Total = 161

solution: General term =  n C 7 1/3 11 1/12   n–r   r r =  n C  7  (11) r/12 n  r 3 r For integral terms, r must be multiple of 12  r = 12k, k W Total values of r = 183 Hence max r = 12(182)  2184 Min value of n = 2184

question_text: 11.  Define a relation R on the interval  0, by x R y 2        if and only if sec2x – tan2y = 1. Then R is :

options.(2): both reflexive and transitive but not symmetric
options.(3): both reflexive and symmetric but not transitive
options.(4): reflexive but neither symmetric not transitive

solution: sec2x – tan2x = 1        (on replacing y with x) Reflexive sec2x – tan2y = 1  1 + tan2x + 1 – sec2y = 1   sec2y – tan2x = 1   symmetric  sec2x – tan2y = 1,  sec2y – tan2z = 1 Adding both  sec2x – tan2y + sec2y – tan2 z = 1 + 1 sec2x + 1 – tan2z = 2 sec2x – tan2z = 1  Transitive hence equivalence relation

solution: (i) Single letter is used , then no. of words = 5 (ii) Two distinct letters are used, then no. of words C   2   10 30  20  500 5   2  6! 6!  2!4! 3!3!     (iii)  Three  distinct  letters  are  used,  then  no.  of words C   900 5 3 6! 2!2!2! Total no. of words = 1405

26. Given below are two statements : one is labelled as Assertion (A) and the other is labelled as Reason (R). Assertion (A) : Choke coil is simply a coil having a large inductance but a small resistance. Choke coils  are  used  with  fluorescent  mercury-tube fittings.  If  household  electric  power  is  directly connected  to  a  mercury  tube,  the  tube  will  be damaged. Reason (R) : By using the choke coil, the voltage across  the  tube  is  reduced  by  a  factor   R R 2  2 L 2 ,  where    is  frequency  of  the supply  across  resistor  R  and  inductor  L.  If  the choke coil were not used, the voltage across the resistor would be the same as the applied voltage. In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: correct explanation of (A). explanation of (A).
solution: A: Correct B : Correct with correct explanation

Reason (R) : Time period of a simple pendulum decreases with increasing value of acceleration due to gravity and vice-versa. In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: correct explanation of (A). explanation of (A).
solution: As h increases, g decreases, T increases T  2  g g  0 (R  h) g R 2 2

question_text: 33.  At  the  interface  between  two  materials  having refractive indices n 1 and n 2, the critical angle for reflection of an em wave is  1C. The n 2 material is replaced  by  another  material  having  refractive index n 3, such that the critical angle at the interface between n 1 and n 3 materials is  2C. If n 3 > n 2 > n 1; 2   and  sin   sin   , then  1C is 3 n 2 1 n 5 2C 1C 2 1 1  1   2  6n 3n       1 1 5 1 6n 3n          
solution: sin   1 1C 2 n n  sin   1 2C n 3 n sin   sin   2 2C 1C 1

question_text: 34.  Consider  a  long  straight  wire  of  a  circular cross-section (radius a) carrying a steady current I. The  current  is  uniformly  distributed  across  this cross-section. The distances from the centre of the wire's  cross-section at which  the  magnetic field [inside the wire, outside the wire] is half of the maximum possible magnetic field, any where due to the wire, will be
solution: Maximum possible magnetic field is at the surface  I B  0 max 2 a max  0 B  I 2 4  a It can be obtained inside as well as outside the wire For inside, 0  0  I  Ir 4  a 2  a 2  r  a 2 For outside 0  0  I  I 4  a 2  r  r = 2a ,2a Correct answer  a      2

question_text: 35.  As shown below, bob A of a pendulum having massless string of length 'R' is released from 60° to the vertical. It hits another bob B of half the mass that is at rest on a friction less table in the centre. Assuming elastic collision, the magnitude of the velocity of bob A after the collision will be (take g as acceleration due to gravity)  A m m/2 B 60° 3 3 3
solution: R  A  B  60°  R/2  R/2  Velocity of a just before hitting : u  2g  gR R 2 Just after collision, let velocity of A and B are v 1 and v 2 respectively  by COM: mu = mv 1 + v 2 m 2 2v 1 + v 2 = 2u     ….(i) e  1  2 1 v  v u  v 2 – v 1 = u     ….(ii) From (i) –(ii)  3v 1 = u  v   gR 1 u 1 3 3

question_text: 36.  Given below are two statements : one is labelled as Assertion (A) and the other is labelled as Reason (R). Assertion  (A)  :  Emission  of  electrons  in photoelectric effect can be suppressed by applying a  sufficiently  negative  electron  potential  to  the photoemissive substance. Reason (R) : A negative electric potential, which stops the emission of electrons from the surface of a  photoemissive  substance,  varies  linearly  with frequency of incident radiation. In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: explanation of (A). correct explanation of (A).
solution: (A) : True (B) : True but not correct explanation

question_text: 37.  A  coil  of  area  A  and  N  turns  is  rotating  with angular velocity  in a uniform magnetic field B about an axis perpendicular to  B. Magnetic flux and induced emf across it, at an instant when B is parallel to the plane of coil, are :
solution:  = BAN.cos(t)  = BAN.sin(t)  d  dt  When B is parallel to plane, t =  2   = 0,  = BAN

question_text: 41.  A body of mass 'm' connected to a massless and unstretchable string goes in verticle circle of radius 'R' under gravity g. The other end of the string is fixed at the center of circle. If velocity at top of circular path is n gR, where, n 1, then ratio of kinetic energy of the body at bottom to that at top of the circle is n  4 n 2n 2 n 2 n 4 n  4 2
solution: V  n 2 gR Top V  n 2 gR  4gR Bottom Ratio  n  4 2 n 2

44.  The workdone in an adiabatic change in an ideal gas depends upon only :
solution: W = –U = – nC VT

question_text: 45.  Given below are two statements : one is labelled as Assertion (A) and other is labelled as Reason (R). Assertion  (A)  :  Electromagnetic  waves  carry energy but not momentum. Reason (R) : Mass of a photon is zero. In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below : correct explanation of (A). explanation of (A).
solution: Assertion  is  false  because  em  waves  have momentum.

question_text: 46.  The coordinates of a particle with respect to origin in a given reference frame is (1, 1, 1) meters. If a force of  F  i  j  k  acts on the particle, then the ˆ ˆ ˆ magnitude  of  torque  (with  respect  to  origin)  in z-direction is _________.

After refraction, the beams intersect at point 3 which is exactly on the interface at other end of the block. Given : the distance  between  1  and  2,  d  4 3cm   and    cos  1 2 ,  where  refractive  index  of 1 2 1 n 2n      the  block  n 2  >  refractive  index  of  the  outside medium  n 1,  then  the  thickness  of  the  block  is ________ cm.   1   2 n 1 1 2 d 3 n 2

49.  In a hydraulic lift, the surface area of the input piston is 6 cm2 and that of the output piston is 1500 cm2. If 100 N force is applied to the input piston to raise the output piston by 20 cm, then the work done is _________ kJ.

50.  The maximum speed of a boat in still water is 27 km/h. Now this boat is moving downstream in a river flowing at 9 km/h. A man in the boat throws a ball  vertically  upwards  with  speed  of  10  m/s. Range of the ball as observed by an observer at rest on the river bank, is _________ cm. (Take g = 10 m/s2)
solution: v  = 9 + 27 = 36 km/hr b  v  36   = 10 m/sec b 36000 1000 Time of flight =   = 2 sec 2  10 10 Range = 10 × 2 = 20m = 2000 cm

question_text: 51. Total number of nucleophiles from the following is :- NH 3,  PhSH,  (H 3C) 2S,  H 2C=CH 2,  OH,  H 3O, (CH 3) 2 CO,   NCH 3
solution: Total five nucleophiles are present NH 3, PhSH, (H 3C) 2S, CH 2=CH 2, OH

question_text: 52. The standard reduction potential values of some of the p-block ions are given below. Predict the one with the strongest oxidising capacity. Sn 4  T l 3  Sn 2  T l E  1.26V Al 3  Pb 4  Al 2  Pb
solution: Standard reduction potential value (+ve) increases oxidising capacity increases.

question_text: 53. The molar conductivity of a weak electrolyte when plotted against the square root of its concentration, which of the following is expected to be observed? observed at infinite dilution. observed at infinite dilution. increase in concentration. increase in concentration.

options.(1): A  small  decrease  in  molar  conductivity  is
options.(2): A  small  increase  in  molar  conductivity  is

solution: Molar conductivity C

56.  Choose the correct statements. (A) Weight of a substance is the amount of matter present in it. (B) Mass is the force exerted by gravity on an object. (C) Volume is the amount of space occupied by a substance. (D)  Temperatures  below  0ºC  are  possible  in Celsius  scale,  but  in  Kelvin  scale  negative temperature is not possible. (E)  Precision  refers  to  the  closeness  of  various measurements for the same quantity.
solution: Theory based

58.  Match List-I with List-II. List-I (Complex) List-II (Hybridisation & Magnetic characters) (A)  [MnBr 4]2–  (I)  d2sp3 & diamagnetic (B)  [FeF (II) 6]3–  sp3d2 & paramagnetic (C)  3]3–  (III) [Co(C 2O 4) sp3 & diamagnetic (D)  (IV) [Ni(CO) 4] sp3 & paramagnetic Choose the correct answer from the options given below :
solution: (A) [MnBr 4]2–  Mn+2  [Ar] 3d5 In presence of ligand field  [Ar]  3d  4s  4p   sp3 hybridization, paramagnetic in nature

question_text: 61.  The correct option with order of melting points of the pairs (Mn, Fe), (Tc, Ru) and (Re, Os) is :

options.(1): Fe < Mn, Ru < Tc and Re < Os
options.(2): Mn < Fe, Tc < Ru and Re < Os
options.(3): Mn < Fe, Tc < Ru and Os < Re
options.(4): Fe < Mn, Ru < Tc and Os < Re

solution: M.P.  Mn < Fe, Tc < Ru, Os < Re NCERT based

question_text: 67.  An element ‘E’ has the ionisation enthalpy value of 374 kJ mol–1. ‘E’ reacts with elements A, B, C and D with electron gain enthalpy values of –328, –349, –325 and –295 kJ mol–1, respectively. The correct order of the products EA, EB, EC and ED in terms of ionic character is :
solution: Difference between I.E. & E.G.E increases, ionic character increases.

List – I    List – II (Carbohydrate)  (Linkage Source) (A)  Amylose  (I)  -C 1-C 4, plant (B)  Cellulose  (II) -C 1-C 4, animal (C)  Glycogen  (III)  -C 1-C 4, -C 1-C 6, plant (D)  Amylopectin  (IV)  -C 1-C 4, plant Choose the correct answer form the options given below :
solution: Informative

question_text: 69.  The  steam  volatile  compounds  among  the following are : (A)  2    (B)   2  OH  NH 2 NO NO (C)    (D)  H 2N  HO OH NH 2 Choose the correct answer from the options given below :
solution: (A)  2 &  (B)   2  OH NO NH 2 NO are steam volatile due to intramolecular hydrogen bonding.

question_text: 70.  Given below are two statements : Statement (I) : The radii of isoelectronic species increases in the order.  Mg2+ < Na+ < F¯ < O2– Statement (II) : The magnitude of electron gain enthalpy of halogen decreases in the order.  Cl  > F > Br  > I

71.  Given  below  are  some  nitrogen  containing compounds.  NH 2 NO 2 CH 2–NH 2 N–COCH 3 H NH 2 Each of them is treated with HCl separately. 1.0 g of  the  most  basic  compound  will  consume ______mg of HCl. (Given molar mass in g mol–1  C:12, H : 1, O : 16, Cl : 35.5)
solution: Benzyl Amine is most basic due to localised lone pair.  CH 2–NH CH 2–NH 3Cl 2 +  HCl    (Benzyl Amine) Mole of benzyl Amine    0.00934  mole 1 107 1 Mole of Benzyl amine consumed 1 mole of HCl So, Mole of HCl consumed  0.00934 mole Mass of HCl consumed  0.00934 × molar mass of HCl = 0.00934 × 36.5 = 0.341 gm = 341 mg

question_text: 72.  The  molar  mass  of  the  water  insoluble  product formed  from the fusion of chromite ore (FeCr 2O 4) with Na 2CO 3 in presence of O 2 is ______g mol–1.
solution: 4FeCr 2O 4 + 8Na 2CO 3 + 7O 2  8Na 2CrO 4 + 2Fe 2O 3 + 8CO 2 Fe 2O 3 is water insoluble, so its molar mass   [2 × 56 + 3 × 16]  160 g/mol

question_text: 73.  The sum of sigma () and pi() bonds in Hex-1,3-dien-5-yne is _______.
solution: H–C=C–C=C–CC–H  H H  H H Number of  bond = 11 Number of  bond = 4  +  = 11 + 4 = 15
